title: Stable Rust erroneously suggests GAT to fix missing lifetime in associated type

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code ([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=90a31f5f0c164d4a9e03e7d99c0fac2f)):

```rust
trait Foo {
    type Bar;
}

struct Baz;

impl Foo for Baz {
    type Bar = &i32;
}

```

The output on stable 1.62.1 is:

```
error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifier
 --> src/lib.rs:8:16
  |
8 |     type Bar = &i32;
  |                ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
help: consider introducing a named lifetime parameter
  |
8 |     type Bar<'a> = &'a i32;
  |             ++++    ++
```

If I do what the compiler says, I (reasonably) get 

```
error[E0658]: generic associated types are unstable
```

and

```
error[E0195]: lifetime parameters or bounds on type `Bar` do not match the trait declaration
```

Interestingly, on nightly the error message is more along the lines of what I'd expect to see on stable:

```
error[E0637]: `&` without an explicit lifetime name cannot be used here
 --> src/lib.rs:8:16
  |
8 |     type Bar = &i32;
  |                ^ explicit lifetime name needed here
```

Based on a quick bisect on rust.godbolt.org, the hint to add a lifetime parameter (a regression) was introduced in 1.42.
